docs.title: First Steps

docs.text:
.sched {
    float: left;
    font-size: 16px;
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 24px;
  }
  .sched-time {
    text-align: right;
    padding-right: 5px;
    width: 15%;
  }
  .sched-text {
    width: 84%;
    padding-left: 5px;
  }
  .sched-subtext {
    padding-left: 25px;
  }






How Smart can you Hack with Spark?






RSVP






Apache Spark has taken the big data community by storm, but what does this mean to you? Come hack with us for a unique opportunity to experiment with capabilities of Spark and a chance to win up to $7,500. This 3-day hackathon will give you the chance to learn, test and extract value using Spark. Our experts will be on hand to offer guidance and tips as you hack your way to the finish.  


Did we mention we will have $10,000 in cash prizes???


Prizes




1st Place: 
$7,500


2nd Place: 
$2,500




Rules




Max of 3 members per team.


Original idea (not submitted to a previous hackathon). You must start coding at the hackathon.


Successfully extract value using Spark.


Use Data Scientist Workbench as the development and demonstration platform.


Submit code to the hackathon's GitHub organization. Your team must include all notebooks created in Data Scientist Workbench.


Present solution to a panel of judges (10 minutes in total for presentation and demo).




Judging Criteria




Innovation:
 How innovative is the solution?


Relevance:
 Does it solve a real problem?


Functionality:
 How functional is your code?




Our Esteemed Panel of Judges




Frank Taylor
, Data Scientist at Personagraph


Mohammed Guller
, Principal Architect at Glassbeam


Ned Shawa
, Solutions Engineer at Hortonworks


Leon Katsnelson
, Director and CTO at IBM


Brandon MacKenzie
, WW Technical Sales at IBM




Schedule


Friday, June 12th


4:00 PM



Registration and Networking



5:00 PM



Welcome and Introductions



5:30 PM



Environment Demo and Hackathon Guidelines



6:00 PM



Dinner, Team breakouts 
&
 idea creation



12:00 AM



Wrap up for the day






Saturday, June 13th


9:00 AM



Breakfast and Announcements



9:45 AM



Get hacking!



12:00 PM



Lunch



6:00 PM



Dinner



12:00 AM



Wrap-up for the day






Sunday, June 14th


9:00 AM



Breakfast and Hack to the finish line



10:30 PM



Hackathon stops! Presentation Prep



11:00 PM



Presentations and lunch






Presentations to a panel of judges






10 minutes each



12:45 PM



Closing announcements



1:00 PM



Doors close








Winners will be announced Tuesday, June 16th!






RSVP






Note there is a seat limit for this hackathon - please make sure you get on Slack to confirm your attendance.

docs.title: Hackathon

docs.text:
Slack
 is an awesome platform for team communication and it's our tool of choice for this hackathon. All the communication will flow through Slack!


You have been sent an invitation for this hackathon's 
Slack team
. In case you haven't received it, please message us at 
 asking for help! Or just find an organizer if you are at the hackathon.





You can use Slack from your Web browser, but we strongly recommend that you the native apps:




Mac OS


Windows


iOS


Android

docs.title: Resources

docs.text:
Have you joined Slack yet?
 We hope so! Now you need to register your team.


Our dearest 
Rosie Jetson
   will be helping us out in this hackathon!
Rosie will register your team in our 
GitHub organization
, or add you to the team, in case another team member has already registered it.


Just say hello to Rosie!
docs.title: Register your Team

docs.text:
Overview


Data Scientist Workbench aims to be your one-stop shop for data science tools. At this time, it is a technology preview limited to IPython/Jupyter notebooks enabled with Spark integration. You will use notebooks to develop and run Spark programs, as well visualize, document and present your analysis. Currently, Spark integration is only supported by the Scala runtime.


Requesting your own Data Scientist Workbench


Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the big blue button. After completing the registration, you will receive an e-mail with instructions.


Hello World


To get a feel of how the Data Scientist Notebooks work with Scala and Spark, follow the steps below to load a "Hello World" notebook along with its sample data.







Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.




Use the search bar to import the following file and notebook.
    

    

    

    






Notebook:
  
https://share.knowledgeanyhow.org/#/api/v1/workbench/10.114.214.68/shares/sHbSUP0luy1xE2q/Scala%20and%20Spark%20in%2015%20minutes.ipynb






Data:

https://share.knowledgeanyhow.org/#/api/v1/workbench/10.114.214.68/shares/t9LwxWg0EkWKMYX/2015.csv










Follow the notebook!
    

    

    

    






For more details on sharing data and notebooks, check 
this guide
.
docs.title: Data Scientist Workbench

You will use notebooks to develop and run Spark programs, as well visualize, document and present your analysis. Currently, Spark integration is only supported by the Scala runtime.

docs.title: Hello World

docs.text:
We are providing an example data set to get you started, but we encourage you to use use your own. You can download it in the link below.


http://bit.ly/SFHackData


Next, you'll probably want to extract the 
zip
 file and 
upload the 
csv
 files to your workbench
.
docs.title: Download Sample Data

docs.text:
Sharing data and notebooks can be very useful for team collaboration.


Exporting Data and Notebooks




Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.


Find the file or notebook you want to share, and click the twistie (
) to the left of it.




Click the 
share
 button (
).
    

    

    

    






Click the 
Show Link
 link to get the link to the shared notebook.




Send this link to the person you're sharing the file or notebook with.




Importing Data and Notebooks




Copy the link of the file or notebook you want to import (from step 5 above).


Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.




Paste the link in the text field at the top right corner of the page.
    

    

    

    






Hit 
Enter
 to import the file or notebook.
docs.title: Sharing Data and Notebooks

docs.text:
Go to  Data Scientist Workbench  and click the  My Notebooks  menu.  Find the file or notebook you want to share, and click the twistie ( ) to the left of it.   Click the  share  button ( ).
     
     
     
        Click the  Show Link  link to get the link to the shared notebook.   Send this link to the person you're sharing the file or notebook with.
docs.title: Exporting Data and Notebooks

docs.text:
Copy the link of the file or notebook you want to import (from step 5 above).  Go to  Data Scientist Workbench  and click the  My Notebooks  menu.   Paste the link in the text field at the top right corner of the page.
     
     
     
        Hit  Enter  to import the file or notebook.
docs.title: Importing Data and Notebooks

docs.text:
To data into your Data Scientist Workbench, all you have to do is:




Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.


Drag the files you want to load from your computer and drop them on DSW.




Note:
 There is no upload progress indication. If you're trying to upload a large file, it might take a few minutes for the upload to complete and the file show up in "Recent Data".
docs.title: Load Data into DSW

docs.text:
R


Use 
install.packages()
 in a R notebook, as shown in the example below.


install.packages(
yaml
, repos=
http://cran.stat.ucla.edu
)




Python


Open a Python notebook and use 
pip
 to install Python packages, as shown below.


!pip install vincent




Scala


Adding new JARs is not officially supported at this time. If you need to do so, please send a direct message to Henrique Zambon on Slack.
